title: How to Freeze and Store Beets

steps.title: Choose beets with smooth skins and no surface cuts or bruises.
steps.content: Choose beets with smooth skins and no surface cuts or bruises. Avoid choosing beets that have flabby skins, are shriveled, or are soft with moist spots. If you happen to have beets that have the leaves attached, make sure they are dark green in color, small, and crisp to the touch. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the roots of the beet and remove the greens.
steps.content: Cut the roots of the beet and remove the greens. Although a knife can be used to cut the roots and greens, using a pair of scissors is easier. In some cases, if you have purchased from a grocery store or a farmer’s market, the greens and part of the roots may have already been removed. [2] X Research source When trimming the beets, leave at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of the roots and 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) of the stems. If any more is removed, the beets may bleed during the cooking process. [3] X Research source Don’t throw the greens away if they are fresh! You can use them in a salad or cook them like spinach and add vinegar, salt, and pepper for added flavor. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wash and scrub the beets under cold running water.
steps.content: Wash and scrub the beets under cold running water. Use a vegetable brush to remove any dirt. No worries if you don’t have one, the beets can be scrubbed with a washcloth just as easily. Place the beets in a colander to drain any excess water. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Bring a large pot of water to boil.
steps.content: Bring a large pot of water to boil. Use high heat and bring your stockpot or large pot to a rolling boil. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Place the cleaned beets in the boiling pot of water and cover.
steps.content: Place the cleaned beets in the boiling pot of water and cover. Cook the beets on lower heat until they are tender. For small beets, this should take 25 to 30 minutes. About 45 to 50 minutes is needed to cook medium to large-sized beets. [7] X Trustworthy Source National Center for Home Food Preservation Publicly-funded center dedicated to educating consumers about research-backed safety practices for preserving food Go to source If you are concerned about the beets bleeding while boiling, add 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of vinegar or lemon juice to the water. [8] X Research source Boiling is the most common way of cooking beets, but they can also be oven roasted. To roast your beets, place the washed and scrubbed beets in a shallow baking dish filled with 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) of water. Cover with aluminum foil, tightly wrap and cook for one hour at 400 °F (204 °C). [9] X Research source Some people choose to steam their beets in preparation for storing. To steam your beets, fill a large stockpot with water and bring to boil. Place the beets in the steamer insert, cover, lower the heat, and cook for about 30 minutes or until done. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Check to see if the beets are tender.
steps.content: Check to see if the beets are tender. As you approach the end of the cooking time, use a knife to check for doneness. Choose the thickest part of a beet and insert a knife or fork. If the knife or fork enters into the beet easily, it’s cooked. If you feel some resistance, the beets need more time to cook. [11] X Research source If your beets are not tender enough, keep checking on them in 15-minute intervals until ready.

steps.title: Drain the cooked beets in a colander and cool in an ice bath.
steps.content: Drain the cooked beets in a colander and cool in an ice bath. Cooling the beets immediately stops the cooking process and makes them safe to handle. Let the beets sit in the ice bath for 5 to 10 minutes. [12] X Research source Cooling the beets in an ice bath also helps to loosen the skins on the beets for easy removal. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the roots and stems with a knife.
steps.content: Remove the roots and stems with a knife. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skins, be careful not to remove more than is necessary. If you don’t have a peeler handy, you can gently rub the skins off under cool running water. Be sure to wear a pair of gloves, to protect against your hands getting stained. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the beets into 1⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) slices.
steps.content: Cut the beets into 1 ⁄ 4 inch (0.64 cm) slices. Alternatively, you can cut into quarters, or dice them. If the beets are around 1 inch (2.5 cm) in size, they can be left whole. However, be aware that whole beets do not freeze as well. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Put the beets into plastic freezer bags.
steps.content: Put the beets into plastic freezer bags. You can use Ziploc bags for freezing. For single servings, the one-quart size is best. Be sure to leave about 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) or 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space at the top of the bag before sealing for storage. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Remove as much air as possible from the plastic bags and tightly seal.
steps.content: Remove as much air as possible from the plastic bags and tightly seal. One way to remove air is to push the air out of the bag and seal it, leaving the end slightly open. At the open end, insert a drinking straw and suck out all of the remaining air and then quickly seal the bag. [17] X Research source Another way of removing air is to use a vacuum sealing system. This method is guaranteed to remove all of the air in the bag and reduce the chance of freezer burn. These systems can be costly, but if used frequently are quite valuable. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Label the plastic bags.
steps.content: Label the plastic bags. Make sure you also note the current date. Beets can be kept for up to 12 months in a deep freezer. If you keep your beets in the freezer for 18 months or longer, they can end up shriveled and soggy. The best time to use the frozen beets is between 6 and 9 months. [19] X Research source
